meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> radical and <kanji>stone</kanji> kanji are the same thing!
The <radical>origin</radical> radical and the <kanji>origin</kanji> kanji are the same!

The <radical>world</radical> radical and the <kanji>world</kanji> kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: <kanji>generation</kanji>. 

Think of it this way: the world is just made up of many different generations of people, plants, and animals all getting along together.

The radical <radical>master</radical> and the kanji <kanji>master</kanji> have the same meanings!

This kanji also means <kanji>main</kanji> because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.

The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>alligators</radical>... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the <kanji>Other</kanji> Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.

The <radical>forehead</radical> of this <radical>beggar</radical> is on the <radical>ground</radical>. Except it's not exactly the ground, it's a giant <kanji>copy</kanji> machine, and he's making copies of his forehead!

If someone tries to dig up <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>private</radical> life, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the <kanji>past</kanji>. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.

There's a <radical>mouth</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of <radical>prison</radical> you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of <kanji>number</kanji>s that you don't understand.
The radical for <radical>center</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>center</kanji> are exactly the same.

If you want to <radical>dry</radical> your <radical>horns</radical> you need to lay them <kanji>flat</kanji>. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's <kanji>peace</kanji>.
Take your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>street</radical> to <kanji>hit</kanji> some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!
Add a <radical>drop</radical> of something magical to <radical>water</radical> and suddenly it turns into big block of <kanji>ice</kanji>, just like that.
There's a <radical>cross</radical> inside your <radical>mouth</radical>, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say, you <kanji>say humbly</kanji>.
The <kanji>plate</kanji> kanji and the <radical>plate</radical> radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
What do you get if you lend a <radical>spirit</radical> your <radical>umbrella</radical>? <kanji>Thanks</kanji>, of course! Especially if that spirit is Totoro, the spirit of the forest.
The <radical>leader</radical> is next to the <radical>tree</radical>. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, <kanji>rest</kanji>ing.

If you go down a <radical>slide</radical> and get <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>legs</radical>, it must have been the fault of the <kanji>previous</kanji> person, aka the person who went down the slide <kanji>ahead</kanji> of you. They should've cleaned off their dirty legs <kanji>before</kanji> they went down the slide, but they didn't, and now you've got dirt all over your legs too.

What is the <radical>evening</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so <kanji>famous</kanji> that everybody knows his <kanji>name</kanji> (“Evening Mouth.”).

You have a <radical>gun</radical> and a <radical>cow</radical>, which must mean it's that time of the <kanji>year</kanji>! Every year on New Year's Eve, you get asked to shoot a cow, as per tradition. You really don't want to though, so you deliberately miss every time.

When the <radical>sun</radical> is above the <radical>cross</radical>, it's time for some people to go church — which is always way too <kanji>early</kanji> on a Sunday, am I right? And if you want to get to church early, you need to be <kanji>fast</kanji>, otherwise you'll be too late.

These days <radical>energy</radical> is the greatest <radical>treasure</radical>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine finding some in a literal treasure chest. As soon as you open it, out bursts the <kanji>energy</kanji> in a kind of <kanji>spirit</kanji> ball.

There is a <radical>leaf</radical> growing out of the <radical>sun</radical>! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a <kanji>hundred</kanji>! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
The <radical>bamboo</radical> radical and the <kanji>bamboo</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
The <radical>thread</radical> radical and <kanji>thread</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
The <radical>ear</radical> radical and <kanji>ear</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
The <radical>insect</radical> radical and <kanji>insect</kanji> are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
Someone's taking <radical>tree</radical> <radical>measurements</radical>… Why are they taking measurements of trees? Because they're planning to cut them down to make their <kanji>village</kanji>.
The radical for <radical>man</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>man</kanji> are exactly the same.
When you see both a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and a <radical>street</radical> in the same place, you have the makings of a whole <kanji>town</kanji>!

All these <radical>flowers</radical> were planted by your <radical>leader</radical> with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>. Now the whole place is absolutely full with beautiful <kanji>flower</kanji>s. Flowers everywhere.
The radical <radical>see</radical> and the kanji <kanji>see</kanji> are exactly the same!
The <radical>shellfish</radical> radical and the <kanji>shellfish</kanji> kanji are the same! It can be just the <kanji>shell</kanji> part too.
The radical for <radical>red</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>red</kanji> are the same thing!

The radical for <radical>foot</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>foot</kanji> are exactly the same.

That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you hop.
The radical <radical>car</radical> and the kanji <kanji>car</kanji> are exactly the same.
The radical <radical>not</radical> and the kanji <kanji>not</kanji> are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>samurai</radical> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <kanji>doing</kanji>.
The <radical>hole</radical> radical and the <kanji>hole</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!

Under his <radical>roof</radical>, the <radical>king</radical> stares into a <radical>drop</radical> of water containing his greatest <kanji>treasure</kanji>. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
